caption_text: The flow-sheet of the apparatus used for methane pyrolysis is shown in Fig. 1. When liquids were used as raw materials they were fed to an externally heated flash evaporator by a peristaltic pump, or, in the case of highly viscous tar or furnace oil, by a positive-displacement pump. The tempera- ture of evaporation was 300°C for ra-heptane, cyclohexane and benzene and 700°C for par- affin oil, fuel oil and tar furnace oil.
raw_window: The flow-sheet of the apparatus used for methane pyrolysis is shown in Fig. 1.

When liquids were used as raw materials they were fed to an externally heated flash evaporator by a peristaltic pump, or, in the case of highly viscous tar or furnace oil, by a positive-displacement pump.
The tempera- ture of evaporation was 300°C for ra-heptane, cyclohexane and benzene and 700°C for par- affin oil, fuel oil and tar furnace oil.

caption_text: Fig. 3. Two kinds of fine disperse carbon obtained from pyrolysis of methane. One of these, spherulitic pyrolytic carbon (SPC), is composed of highly anisotropic spheres up to several microns across.

caption_text: Gradual build-up of pyrolytic carbon on the surface of contact material caused a continuous decrease with time in the porosity and surface area of the support (Fig. 5). The data of Table 1 show that the yield of surface carbon generally diminished with decreasing surface area of the support, while the proportion of fine carbon in the total pyrolytic carbon increased. The yield curves of total, surface, and fine carbon are shown in Fig. 6.
raw_window: Gradual build-up of pyrolytic carbon on the surface of contact material caused a continuous decrease with time in the porosity and surface area of the support (Fig. 5).

The data of Table 1 show that the yield of surface carbon generally diminished with decreasing surface area of the support, while the proportion of fine carbon in the total pyrolytic carbon increased.
The yield curves of total, surface, and fine carbon are shown in Fig. 6.

caption_text: Using Fig. 5, carbon yields based on weight measurements after runs were assigned to the mean surface area calculated for the period of a run. The variation of the total yield of carbon, with changes in the surface area of contact material as shown by Line 1 in Fig. 6, was associated with changes in the rate of forma- tion of surface carbon (Line 2) and of fine carbon (Line 3). As the surface area of the coke support decreased there was at first a decline in the total yield of carbon, since the formation of surface carbon was decreasing and practically no fine carbon was being formed.

caption_text: If adequate surface is available the complexes are adsorbed and align themselves on the surface of the substrate, yielding optically anisotropic pyrolytic carbon with well-defined growth cones and of low porosity (as shown in Fig. 2). In the absence of a sufficiently large surface the complexes undergo further condensation and polymerization reactions leading to carbon formation, probably through 'droplets', in the gas phase. This process is faster than the surface growth of complexes and, since little or no alignment 266 J.

caption_text: can occur, fine disperse carbon of isotropic structure is formed (see Fig. 3). From the present experiments the follow- ing can be added to the above observations: (1) The main condition of the formation of surface pyrolytic carbon appears to be an equilibrium between the formation of 'complexes' in the gas phase and their adsorption and growth on the substrate. Bokros [12] found that if the concentration of complexes in the gas phase is too low, the anisotropy of the structures is reduced.
raw_window: can occur, fine disperse carbon of isotropic structure is formed (see Fig. 3).

From the present experiments the follow- ing can be added to the above observations: (1) The main condition of the formation of surface pyrolytic carbon appears to be an equilibrium between the formation of 'complexes' in the gas phase and their adsorption and growth on the substrate.
Bokros [12] found that if the concentration of complexes in the gas phase is too low, the anisotropy of the structures is reduced.

caption_text: (To a lesser extent the formation of anisotropic surface carbon on gas-borne particles of fine carbon has also been observed to occur, as shown in Fig. 3). Although the surface area of the coke support decreases with time, the total available surface area in the reactor increases as the formation of fine carbon becomes intensive. This and the different nature of the surface may account for the increase of total carbon yield observed at low values of support surface.
raw_window: (To a lesser extent the formation of anisotropic surface carbon on gas-borne particles of fine carbon has also been observed to occur, as shown in Fig. 3).
Although the surface area of the coke support decreases with time, the total available surface area in the reactor increases as the formation of fine carbon becomes intensive.
This and the different nature of the surface may account for the increase of total carbon yield observed at low values of support surface.

caption_text: The histograms in Fig. 7 show that admix- ture of oxygen, nitric oxide, carbon dioxide or chlorine to methane did not affect the yields of cracking reactions appreciably, but, as indicated in columns 6 and 7, hydrogen bromide and iodine gave marked catalytic effects. At 1100°C the addition of 2-5 per cent by weight of iodine to methane resulted in an increase of total conversion from 53-5 to 65 per cent, while the yield of carbon in- creased from 46-0 to 57-7 per cent. F.xperiments carried out at 1190°C (see Fig. 8) confirmed the strong catalytic effect of iodine.
raw_window: The histograms in Fig. 7 show that admix- ture of oxygen, nitric oxide, carbon dioxide or chlorine to methane did not affect the yields of cracking reactions appreciably, but, as indicated in columns 6 and 7, hydrogen bromide and iodine gave marked catalytic effects.

At 1100°C the addition of 2-5 per cent by weight of iodine to methane resulted in an increase of total conversion from 53-5 to 65 per cent, while the yield of carbon in- creased from 46-0 to 57-7 per cent.
F.xperiments carried out at 1190°C (see Fig. 8) confirmed the strong catalytic effect of iodine.

matic compound (benzene) than from either a naphthenic molecule (cyclohexane) or a paraffin hydrocarbon (ra-heptane).

caption_text: As Fig. 10 shows, the proportion of fine carbon in the total carbon yield was mainly dependent on the size of the parent molecule and was not greatly influenced by the type of bonding in the molecule.* As mentioned earlier, the number of re- actant molecules passing through the reactor in unit time was the same in all runs. Since large molecules can be cracked more easily *Fuel oil (column 6, Fig. 9) was an exception, in that both the total yield of carbon and the amount of fine carbon were less than expected on the basis of molecular weight. The paraffinic nature of this oil probably explains the lower total carbon yield, while adhesion of fine carbon to lumps of support plus surface carbon during the separation process may have been responsible for the lower yield of fine carbon.

Since large molecules can be cracked more easily *Fuel oil (column 6, Fig. 9) was an exception, in that both the total yield of carbon and the amount of fine carbon were less than expected on the basis of molecular weight.

The paraffinic nature of this oil probably explains the lower total carbon yield, while adhesion of fine carbon to lumps of support plus surface carbon during the separation process may have been responsible for the lower yield of fine carbon.

caption_text: The results of reactivity tests are summarized in Table 2, which shows that the surface carbon had the highest resistance to oxidation (a property highly desirable in carbon anodes used in the elec- trolytic smelting of alumina). The reactivity of pyrolytic carbon obtained from tar was somewhat higher, and about the same as that of the high-temperature coke used as support in the methane cracking tests. These materials were all less reactive than graphite, but on the other hand a sample of calcined petroleum coke used in the aluminium industry had a higher reactivity.
raw_window: The results of reactivity tests are summarized in Table 2, which shows that the surface carbon had the highest resistance to oxidation (a property highly desirable in carbon anodes used in the elec- trolytic smelting of alumina).
The reactivity of pyrolytic carbon obtained from tar was somewhat higher, and about the same as that of the high-temperature coke used as support in the methane cracking tests.
These materials were all less reactive than graphite, but on the other hand a sample of calcined petroleum coke used in the aluminium industry had a higher reactivity.
